meanings.def: to damage something by pulling it apart or into pieces or by cutting it on something sharp; to become damaged in this way
examples: tear something + adv./prep. I tore my jeans on the fence.
I tore a hole in my jeans.
He tore the letter in two.
I tore the picture into pieces.
The letter had been torn to shreds.
tear (something) His clothes were badly torn.
Careful—the fabric tears very easily.
tear something + adj. I tore the package open.
I tore open the package.
The fabric snagged and tore at the seams.
His jacket had been torn to shreds on the barbed wire.

meanings.def: to make a hole in something by force
examples: The blast tore a hole in the wall.

meanings.def: to remove something from something else by pulling it roughly or violently
examples: The storm nearly tore the roof off.
I tore another sheet from the pad.
He tore his clothes off (= took them off quickly and carelessly) and dived into the lake.
an article torn from a magazine
Several pages had been torn out of the book.
She tore the label off the suitcase.
Our posters were torn down as quickly as we could put them up.

meanings.def: to pull yourself/somebody away by force from somebody/something that is holding you or them
examples: tear yourself/somebody from somebody/something She tore herself from his grasp.
tear yourself/somebody + adj. He tore himself free.
One error and he would have been torn loose and hurled overboard by the squalling wind.

meanings.def: to injure a muscle, etc. by stretching it too much
examples: a torn ligament/muscle
She's torn a ligament in her right hand.
She tore a calf muscle playing squash.

meanings.def: to move somewhere very quickly or in an excited way
examples: He tore off down the street.
A truck tore past the gates.
The girls looked at each other and tore off towards the house.
A dog was tearing along the road beside the truck.

meanings.def: very badly affected or damaged by something
examples: to bring peace to a strife-torn country
a strike-torn industry

meanings.def: to be unable to decide or choose between two people, things or feelings
examples: I was torn between my parents and my friend.

meanings.def: to criticize somebody, or their work or ideas, very severely
to destroy or defeat somebody/something completely or criticize them or it severely
examples: We tore the other team apart in the second half.
The critics tore his last movie to shreds.

meanings.def: to strongly affect you in an emotional way
to show that you are very angry or anxious about something
examples: She's keeping very calm—anyone else would be tearing their hair out.
I felt like tearing my hair out in frustration.

meanings.def: to destroy the most important part or aspect of something
examples: Closing the factory tore the heart out of the community.

meanings.def: (to be) in a very great hurry
to attack somebody very violently
to speak angrily to somebody who has done something wrong
used to say that something has happened to cause your plans to fail

examples: This sheet has a tear in it.

meanings.def: to be enjoying great success
examples: Business confidence has soared and the economy is on a tear.
The team has been on a tear since defeating the Red Sox in May.

meanings.def: the damage to objects, furniture, property, etc. that is the result of normal use
examples: The insurance policy does not cover damage caused by normal wear and tear.
The living-room carpet has to stand up to the combined wear and tear of two dogs and three children.
